newsitem.title: CHINA: Foreign banks seen far from China yuan business.
newsitem.headline: Foreign banks seen far from China yuan business.

text.p: China is still far from implementing long-promised plans to open the domestic currency business to foreign banks, a Western analyst of the China market said on Wednesday.
"The feeling is that foreign banks will not be doing renminbi (Chinese currency) business anytime soon," said Lois Tretiak, vice president of the Economist Group's business conference unit.

Tretiak, a long-time analyst of China economic and political developments, made the remarks to reporters after a business conference that included members of China's central bank, the People's Bank of China.
"They seemed to be saying 'we want this to happen but we will not predict when'."
Foreign banks, now confined to foreign currency business, have long been pushing to be allowed to take deposits and make loans in domestic currency.
China has signalled that it would permit local currency business in the future in the Pudong district of Shanghai as part of efforts to speed development of the east China city as a financial centre.
But Tretiak said Chinese bankers at the conference made no reference to plans for Pudong in this area, even on an experimental basis.
Plans seemed to be slowed by opposition from Chinese commercial banks to competition from foreign financial insitutitions, she said.
